citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the facility is the principal investigator and the IACUC chairman. The CEO prepares
and submits the proposals for research activities and retains voting rights for approval of said proposals. In addition, the
APHIS official observed that the CEO had not appointed the IACUC members to the committee. Serving in the roles of
CEO and IACUC Chair while retaining voting rights as the principal investigator compromises the ability of the IACUC to
ensure the proper care and treatment of animals used in the research program and the ability to perform the functions
required by the Animal Welfare Act.
The Chief Executive Officer of the research facility shall appoint an Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee
(IACUC), qualified through the experience and expertise of its members to assess the research facility’s animal program,
facilities, and procedures.
To be corrected by February 15, 2025.

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The two semi-annual reports reviewed by the APHIS official for 2024 were not signed by a majority of the IACUC
members. The semi-annual reports shall include a review of the research facility’s program of humane care and use of
animals as well as an inspection of the animal facilities at least every six months. Signatures of the IACUC members
ensure that the committee is documenting their accountability for the oversight of the animal care and use program.
Reports to the Institutional Official or CEO shall be reviewed and signed by a majority of the IACUC and updated upon
completion of the required semi-annual evaluations.
To Be Corrected by the next semi-annual report to the Institutional Official in or before May 2025

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
Multiple pigs, on multiple dates, undergoing anesthesia for study related surgeries were not monitored while under
anesthesia as specified in their assigned protocol. The protocol indicates that vital parameters including, but not limited to,
heart rate, respiratory rate, and temperature are to be monitored and documented every hour. However, observation
during inspection and review of records revealed that study personnel failed to monitor and document vital signs every
hour on multiple animals during multiple sessions. This constitutes a significant change to the protocol reviewed by the
IACUC.
Unapproved changes in animal use activities can be detrimental to animal health, because it could result in a failure to
recognize and address pain and distress in animals. The IACUC must review and approve proposed significant changes
regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities.
To be corrected by January 31, 2025.

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
Review of the study protocol revealed the principal investigator did not provide a written narrative description of the
methods and sources used to determine that alternatives were not available to the surgical procedures performed in the
study.
Per this Section, whenever a proposal for animal use contains procedures that may cause more than momentary pain or
distress to the animals, the IACUC shall determine that: (1) the principal investigator has considered alternatives to those
procedures and (2) that the principal investigator has provided a written narrative description of the methods and sources
used to determine that alternatives were not available. These requirements ensure that all procedures contained in the
protocol minimize discomfort, distress, and pain to the animals. The IACUC needs to address this item.

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
The research facility’s study protocol does not include a complete description of how animals will be used. The protocol
discusses the use of animals as tissue models and describes anesthetic and euthanasia protocols. However, there is no
description of the surgical procedures or activities that require the use of the animals as models for medical training. A
complete description of animal use is required for Institutional Animal Use and Care Committee (IACUC) review and
approval of activities related to the care and use of animals.
A complete description of procedures of proposed animal use is necessary to ensure that the IACUC has all information
needed to approve animal activities, that all study staff understand what the approved procedures are, that painful
procedures will be performed with appropriate anesthetics, and the attending veterinarian has been involved in the
planning.
To be corrected by 2/15/2025.

citations.desc: Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).
citations.narrative:
On January 14, 2024, an anesthetized pig, patient #6, was undergoing a study-related surgery and observed to be
reacting to surgical stimuli. The pig was observed to be exhibiting a palpebral (blink) response, moving its head towards
its chest, and retracting its limbs when study personnel applied surgical stimuli multiple times during a one-hour period.
Study personnel administered additional anesthesia six times during the one-hour period from 1100 hours to 1200 hours.
They would attempt surgical manipulation after administering anesthetic injection, but the pig continued to react to painful
(or surgical-if you prefer) stimuli. Failure to provide adequate analgesic and anesthetic drugs may result in unnecessary
pain and distress to the animals.
In addition, the study protocol does not describe the point at which an animal that is experiencing problems would be
removed from study to prevent animals being subjected to procedures and unnecessary pain or distress beyond that
which is necessary for scientifically valuable research.
A proposal to conduct an activity involving animals must provide a description of procedures designed to assure that
discomfort and pain to animals will be limited to that which is unavoidable for the conduct of scientifically valuable
research, including provision for the use of analgesic, anesthetic, and tranquilizing drugs where indicated and appropriate
to minimize discomfort and pain to animals.
Corrected at time of inspection.

citations.desc: Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care.
citations.narrative:
According to facility records, on October 22, 2024, during a training session under the facility’s protocol, three pigs died
under general anesthesia. Anesthesia records indicate the animals developed hyperthermia with temperature ranges from
approximately 105° F to 108° F at the time of death. Veterinary treatment for this condition was not provided to these
animals and training procedures continued for 2-5 hours before the pigs died. In addition, on November 17, 2024, records
indicate two pigs died under anesthesia from suspected respiratory distress. For the health and safety of the animals,
appropriate methods should be in place in the event of emergencies or animals in distress.
Each research facility shall establish appropriate methods to prevent, control, diagnose, and treat diseases and the
availability of emergency care.
To be corrected by close of business January 15, 2025.

The facility's annual report for fiscal year 2024, which was due to the Deputy Administrator on or before December 1st,
2024, was not submitted. Annual reports from 2021, 2022, and 2023 were also not received by the required deadline. In
order to assure that professionally acceptable standards governing the care and use of animals are followed, each
reporting facility shall submit an annual report covering the use of live animals in the previous federal fiscal year on or
before December 1st of each calendar year.
The Annual Report of Research Facility (APHIS Form 7023), Continuation Sheet for Annual Report of Research Facility
(APHIS Form 7023A), and Annual Report of Research Facility Column E Explanation (APHIS Form 7023B) are forms
which may be used to submit the information required by paragraph (b) of this section.

This facility has not yet developed and documented an appropriate plan for their animals in event of an emergency or
disaster.
Research facilities must develop, document, and follow an appropriate plan to provide for the humane handling,
treatment, transportation, housing, and care of their animals in the event of an emergency or disaster (one which could
reasonably be anticipated and expected to be detrimental to the good health and well-being of the animals in their
possession).
To be corrected by February 15, 2025
This inspection and exit interview were conducted with facility representatives.
n

narrative:
2.31(b)(1) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC). 
The Chief Executive Officer (CEO) of the facility is the principal investigator and the IACUC chairman. The CEO prepares

required by the Animal Welfare Act.  
 
The Chief Executive Officer of the research facility shall appoint an Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee

To Be Corrected by the next semi-annual report to the Institutional Official in or before May 2025 
2.31(c)(7) 
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).

Multiple pigs, on multiple dates, undergoing anesthesia for study related surgeries were not monitored while under

hour on multiple animals during multiple sessions. This constitutes a significant change to the protocol reviewed by the

Unapproved changes in animal use activities can be detrimental to animal health, because it could result in a failure to 
recognize and address pain and distress in animals. The IACUC must review and approve proposed significant changes 
regarding the care and use of animals in ongoing activities. 
 
 
To be corrected by January 31, 2025.

2.31(e)(4)  Direct
   
Institutional Animal Care and Use Committee (IACUC).

2.33(b)(2)  Critical
   
Attending veterinarian and adequate veterinary care. 
According to facility records, on October 22, 2024, during a training session under the facility’s protocol, three pigs died

species.common: DOMESTIC PIG / POTBELLY PIG / MICRO PIG
